back.definition: Detect brute force, credential stuffing. Multiple failed logins followed by success = compromise. Geographic anomalies.
back.example: Alert: 100 failed logins to admin account from IP in Russia, then 1 success. SIEM correlates events. Target: Fazio creds from unusual location.

back.definition: Large outbound transfers to unusual destinations. DNS queries with high entropy (tunneling). Upload to cloud storage anomalies.
back.example: SIEM: User uploaded 10GB to personal Dropbox in 1 hour. Baseline: User averages 10MB/day. Alert triggered. Target: Exfil to Brazil/Russia.

back.definition: Admin accounts used outside business hours, from unusual locations, unusual commands. Service accounts login interactively (abnormal).
back.example: Alert: Domain Admin account login at 3am on Saturday. Investigation: Compromised. Twitter: Internal admin tool abuse detected this way.

back.definition: Beaconing: Regular intervals to external IP. DNS to known bad domains. TLS to unusual ports. HTTP POST to suspicious URLs.
back.example: SIEM + Threat Intel: DNS query to domain in threat feed = alert. Colonial: DarkSide C2 beaconing could be detected.

unlock_content.title: Use Case Definition
points: Business driver: Compliance, threat intel, past incident, industry trend
Example: 'Detect ransomware lateral movement via SMB'
Success criteria: What alert looks like? Acceptable false positive rate?
Data sources needed: Which logs required?
Target example: 'Detect POS malware memory access'
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Good use case: Specific, actionable, measurable. Bad: Too broad ('detect all attacks').

unlock_content.title: Rule Development
points: SIEM query language: SPL (Splunk), KQL (Sentinel), etc
Logic: IF (condition1 AND condition2) THEN alert
Example: IF (process='powershell.exe' AND cmdline contains 'Invoke-Mimikatz') THEN High Severity Alert
Thresholds: 5+ failed logins in 10 min from single IP
Exclusions: Whitelist known good (scanner IPs, maintenance accounts)
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Start strict, tune over time. Better initial false positives than miss true threats.

unlock_content.title: Rule Testing
points: Simulate attack: Use purple team to generate events
Historical data: Replay past logs. Does rule catch known incident?
False positive check: Run against baseline. Too noisy?
Severity tuning: Critical vs High vs Medium
Target test: Replay BlackPOS logs. Does rule trigger?
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Never deploy rule to production without testing. One bad rule = alert storm = SOC down.

unlock_content.title: Rule Lifecycle
points: Deploy: Enable in production SIEM
Monitor: Track alert volume, false positive rate
Tune: Adjust thresholds, add exceptions, refine logic
Sunset: Disable outdated rules (threat no longer relevant)
Document: Maintain rule library with descriptions, owners
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Rule maintenance = 30-40% of detection engineering time. Old rules accumulate like code debt.

options.text: No es importante, rules son set-and-forget
options.feedback: Incorrecto. Opposite. Rules need constant tuning.

options.text: Reduce false positives, improve detection accuracy, adapt to environment changes
options.feedback: CORRECTO! 1) Reduce FPs: Initial rule = noisy. Tuning adds exceptions, adjusts thresholds. 2) Improve accuracy: Attackers evolve. Rules must adapt. 3) Environment changes: New apps, new users = new baselines. 4) Alert fatigue prevention: Untuned rules = alert storm = analysts numb. Target lesson: FireEye alerts ignored partly due to alert fatigue from noisy rules. Well-tuned rules = SOC can focus on real threats.
Incorrecto. Compliance es benefit pero primary goal es effective detection.
